Hello Ray,

On 8/4/06, Ray V <ttftestrayv@...> wrote:
 I'd like to add that in my recent experience on a team
 of 4 developers, it's been very hard to convince the
 others of the value of the unit tests. I find they
 rarely run the tests that are there, often check in
 code that breaks the tests (but not the build), and
 they very frequently add new code that's untested.

I have found myself in this situation more often than I would like.  Up to
now, I have found the best thing to do is wait for someone to check in a
failing test.  Once the test fails, I invest some time determining why.
Normally, I find that:

a) Object behavior has changed, and certain corner cases the developer
didn't manually test for arenow failing.  This is an excellent opportunity
to bring the failure to the developer in question and let them know.  When
they ask how you found out so quickly, you can demonstrate the value of the
tests.

b) Something trivial has changed - for example a toString() method now
returns something different.  This is usually an indication of a test that
is too dependent upon the implementation and is fragile.  This is an
exellent learning opportunity for yourself - what is the test really
testing?  How can it be rewritten so that these trivial changes won't cause
problems?

c) Something about the design has changed - instead of injecting a
collaborator the code now creates one.  I've had the most trouble with these
failures.  If the people writing the code don't value tests, and don't
understand the value of dependency injection outside of tests, it can
quickly turn negative.  I tend to clean these up quietly and promote
Dependency Injection as a best practice when the team talks about design.
I'm sure there are better ways to handle it - I'd love to hear some from the
people on the list.

My personal advice is to keep unit testing.  It can be extremely frustrating
"playing catchup", however you can't beat that rewarding feeling when other
developers on your team starts promoting them too.

Cheers!
Carl
